info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 2, game 15.

(1, 1).clue: You should have heard my "boo-yah!" in 2004 when Shaun Alexander scored his NFL-leading 20th of these

(2, 1).clue: This campaigning term came from a tree part on which frontier speechmakers stood

(6, 1).clue: This word begins a rhyme about what a bride needs on her wedding day

(1, 2).clue: Straight-up swap at this position, Roethlisberger for Culpepper... what do you say?

(2, 2).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew points to a butterfly ballot in a voting booth at the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia, PA.)  Florida voting machines introduced this 4-letter word to many people's vocabularies in 2000

(3, 2).clue: Lots of good eating on U.S. 41--there's a seafood restaurant in this "colorful" chain launched in Florida in 1968

(4, 2).clue: May 13, 1787:11 ships leave England on a voyage that ends by establishing a penal colony here

(5, 2).clue: Lightning rod Scottish politician Jimmy Wray is a member of the British parliament for this political party

(6, 2).clue: Rice paddies release this greenhouse gas

(1, 3).clue: I'm glad I traded for this flamboyant receiver who went from Frisco to Philly in 2004

(2, 3).clue: Authority from the people to govern a certain way, or from the League of Nations to administer an area

(3, 3).clue: The culinary delights of U.S. 41 include this pizza chain founded by John Schnatter downstate in Jeffersonville, In.

(4, 3).clue: May 31, 1913:The 17th Amendment is ratified, authorizing the direct election of these

(5, 3).clue: With an average speed around 133 mph, Jimmy Bryan won this race in 1958

(6, 3).clue: Term originally applied to a mid-18th century religious society founded at Oxford

(1, 4).clue: I'm expecting a few long ones from the well-named Ryan Longwell, a regular at this position

(2, 4).clue: There are 2 "re" processes that changes the areas House seats represent: reapportionment & this

(3, 4).clue: Any day of the week, hit this chain on U.S. 41 for a Three-For-All wings, skins & mozzarella appetizer

(4, 4).clue: May 10, 1941:He parachutes into Scotland with a "peace plan"

(5, 4).clue: He won a 1986 Pulitzer for his work as a columnist for the New York Daily News

(6, 4).clue: His group won a Grammy in 1998 for "Imaginary Day"

(1, 5).clue: Letting go of this Rams back with almost 12,000 career rushing yards could come back to haunt me

(2, 5).clue: The government system used by the U.S.; it divides power between the central & state governments

(3, 5).clue: If this school's 11,200 students tire of chain food, they hit Poplar Street for steaks at Stables

(4, 5).clue: May 15, 1756:This European war begins when England declares war on France

(5, 5).clue: In 1922 he was the first pilot to cross the U.S. in under 24 hours

(6, 5).clue: In mythology, the husband of Pandora & brother of Prometheus; in astronomy, a moon of Saturn

(1, 1).clue: Paul Gallico owned 23 of these animals at a time & wrote a fantasy about a boy who's changed into a white one

(2, 1).clue: In an Oscar acceptance speech, he thanked Joey LaMotta, "even though he's suing us"

(4, 1).clue: When Steve Ballmer became CEO, this man's new role was "Chief Software Architect"

(5, 1).clue: Penillion, a traditional form of Welsh singing, is almost always accompanied by this musical instrument

(6, 1).clue: In Gaelic, this body, set up in 1999 for the first time since 1707, is Pàrlamaid na h-Alba

(1, 2).clue: Mom threw out all my Pern--Anne McCaffrey's books about Pern, where people ride these mythical beasts

(2, 2).clue: Hoo ah!  He turned down the role of Han Solo in "Star Wars"; maybe he should've turned down "Gigli", too

(4, 2).clue: In 1995, this product "95" sold more than 1 million copies in 4 days

(5, 2).clue: This notation used to indicate that the music should get softer is often abbreviated dim.

(6, 2).clue: Nic, "daughter of", is the female equivalent of this 3-letter form seen in many surnames

(4, 3).clue: In March 2004 this body hit Microsoft with a 497 million-euro fine for its bus. practices (take it out of petty cash)

(5, 3).clue: One movement of this famous set of symphonic sketches is called "Jeux de vagues" ("The Play of the Waves")

(6, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew points to a blackboard.)  In Gaelic, "à" means this, as in "Tha mi à glaschu"; it can mean the exact opposite in French

(1, 4).clue: Terry Pratchett created this round "world" that rests on elephants resting on a turtle

(2, 4).clue: Mira's dad, he played Henry Kissinger in 1995's "Nixon"

(4, 4).clue: Now both an NFL & NBA team owner, he co-wrote a "BASIC" computer language for the Altair 8800 in 1975

(5, 4).clue: Tales of Tapio, a Finnish forest god, inspired "Tapiola", this composer's last major symphonic work

(6, 4).clue: If you know cardhu ("black rock") & laphroaig ("beautiful hollow by the broad bay") you either love Gaelic or this

(1, 5).clue: Xanth is a land created by this writer, & if you say his first & last name you'll hear "Xanth" in the middle

(4, 5).clue: MS-DOS for short, this was introduced on IBM personal computers in 1981

(5, 5).clue: He wrote 4 "Mephisto Waltzes", but the last was unfinished when he died in 1886

(0, 0).clue: It refers to a mythical bird that calmed waves, or to past happy "days"; spelled differently, it's a sleeping pill
